{{Infobox Museum |name = Acropolis Museum |native_name = Μουσείο Ακρόπολης |logo = |image = 20140407 athenes44.JPG |caption = |alt = Location of Acropolis Museum in Athens |pushpin_map = Greece Athens central |map_type = Athens |map_relief = |map_size = |map_caption = | coordinates = {{Coord|37.969108|N|23.728299|E|type:landmark_region:GR_scale:2500| display=inline, title}} |established = {{Start date|2009|6|20|df=y}} [http://video.minpress.gr/wwwminpress/Wonderful_Greece/WG_9_3 Wonderful Greece] |location = [[Dionysiou Areopagitou Street]]
[[Athens]], [[Greece]] |type = Archaeological Museum |collection = 4,250+ objects |visitors = 1,475,022 (June 2016–May 2017){{cite web|url=https://issuu.com/theacropolismuseum/docs/acropolis_report_web_gr |title=Yearly statistics|accessdate=2017-06-28}} |director = [[Dimitrios Pandermalis]] |president = |curator = |owner = [[Ministry of Culture and Tourism (Greece)|Hellenic Ministry of Culture and Tourism]] |publictransit = {{OASA icons|M|15}} {{OASA icons|M2|15}} [[Akropoli metro station|Akropoli]] |car_park = |network = |website = [http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/?pname=Home&la=2 www.theacropolismuseum.gr] }} The '''Acropolis Museum''' ({{lang-el|Μουσείο Ακρόπολης}}, ''Mouseio Akropolis'') is an [[archaeological museum]] focused on the findings of the archaeological site of the [[Acropolis of Athens]]. The museum was built to house every artifact found on the rock and on the surrounding slopes, from the [[Greek Bronze Age]] to [[Roman Greece|Roman]] and [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine Greece]]. It also lies over the ruins of a part of Roman and early Byzantine [[Athens]]. The museum was founded in 2003, while the Organization of the Museum was established in 2008. It opened to the public on 20 June 2009. Nearly 4,000 objects are exhibited over an area of 14,000 square metres. The Organization for the Construction of the new museum is chaired by [[Aristotle University of Thessaloniki]] [[Professor Emeritus]] of [[Archaeology]], [[Dimitrios Pandermalis]]. ==History== The [[Old Acropolis Museum|first museum]] was on the Acropolis; it was completed in 1874 and underwent a moderate expansion in the 1950s. However, successive excavations on the Acropolis uncovered many new artifacts which significantly exceeded its original capacity. An additional motivation for the construction of a new museum was that in the past, when Greece made requests for the return of the [[Elgin Marbles|Parthenon Marbles]] from the United Kingdom, which acquired the items in a controversial manner, it was suggested by some British officials that Greece had no suitable location where they could be displayed. Creation of a gallery for the display of the Parthenon Marbles has been key to all recent proposals for the design of a new museum. ===Competitions for the new museum=== [[Image:M01.jpg|thumb|250px|The archaeological site over which the new museum is built - the pink [[Museum of the Center for the Acropolis Studies|Weiler Building]] is seen top right, the two buildings scheduled for demolition are seen top left, with the hill of Lycabettus barely visible behind them]] [[Image:Makrigianni037jqnfo.jpg|thumb|250px|Εarthworks in the archaeological site in Makrygianni, during the construction of the museum.]] The first architectural competition to design a new museum was held in 1976 and was limited to participants from Greece. Both the 1976 competition and one that followed it in 1979 failed to produce any results mainly because the plots of land selected for the proposed constructions were deemed unsuitable. In 1989, a third competition for the design of the new Acropolis Museum was announced that would be international. A choice of three possible sites was provided. This competition was won by the Italian architects, [[Manfredi Nicoletti]] and Lucio Passarelli. After delays throughout the 1990s, work on the construction of the museum based on this third design progressed to the stage of excavations for the foundations, but these were stopped due to apparently sensitive archaeological remains on the site, leading to annulment of the competition in 1999. In retrospect, the location of the new museum was rather straightforward: the large lot of the unused "Camp [[Ioannis Makrygiannis|Makrygianni]]" [[Greek Gendarmerie|gendarmerie]] [[barracks]], opposite the [[Theater of Dionysus]]. The barracks were built on public land and a limited number of expropriations of surrounding private houses were needed to free up the necessary space. The main building of the old barracks, the [[neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] "Weiler Building", has been renovated and houses the [[Museum of the Center for the Acropolis Studies]]. The fourth competition had made no provision for the preservation of the ancient site. These were met to a degree only after local and international ([[ICOMOS]]) campaigners exposed this oversight and it became the final competition. The new plans were adjusted so that the building was elevated above ground, on pillars. Competition was open only to architectural practices by invitation and it was won by New York–based architect, [[Bernard Tschumi]], in collaboration with the Greek architect [[Michael Photiadis]]. Excavation has revealed two layers of modest, private roadside houses and workshops, one from the early Byzantine era and another from the classical era. Once the layout and [[stratigraphy]] of the findings were established, suitable locations for the foundation pillars were identified. These traverse the soil to the underlying [[bedrock]] and float on roller bearings able to withstand a [[Richter magnitude scale|Richter scale magnitude]] 10 earthquake. As construction work neared completion, the operation to move the historic [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] the {{convert|280|m|yd|sp=us|adj=on|lk=out}} distance from the Acropolis rock to the new museum started in October 2007, took four months, and required the use of three [[Crane (machine)#Fixed|tower cranes]] to move the sculptures across the distance without mishap. Greek officials expressed their hope that the new museum will help in the campaign for the return of the [[Parthenon Marbles]].[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7044407.stm BBC News], ''Cranes move Acropolis sculptures'', Retrieved on 2007-10-15.[http://www.ana-mpa.gr/anaweb/user/selectlang?lang=el&currpageurl=%2Fuser%2Fshowplain%3Fmaindoc%3D5726043%26maindocimg%3D5725562%26service%3D6 Athens Press Agency, Macedonian Press Agency] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204235524/http://www.ana-mpa.gr/anaweb/user/selectlang?lang=el&currpageurl=%2Fuser%2Fshowplain%3Fmaindoc%3D5726043&maindocimg=5725562&service=6 |date=December 4, 2007 }}, ''New Acropolis Museum to open in stages in 2008'', Retrieved on 2008-10-18. ==Location== [[File:Acropolis and Acropolis Museum.jpg|thumb|250px|Parthenon (left) and Acropolis Museum (right).]] The museum is located by the southeastern slope of the Acropolis hill, on the ancient road that led up to the "sacred rock" in classical times. Set only {{convert|280|m|yd|sp=us}}, away from the [[Parthenon]], and a mere {{convert|400|m|yd|sp=us}} walking distance from it, the museum is the largest modern building erected so close to the ancient site,{{citation needed|date=April 2016}} although many other buildings from the last 150 years are located closer to the Acropolis. The entrance to the building is on [[Dionysiou Areopagitou Street]] and directly adjacent to the [[Akropoli metro station]] the red line of the [[Athens Metro]]. ==The building== The design by [[Bernard Tschumi]] was selected as the winning project in the fourth competition. Tschumi's design revolves around three concepts: light, movement, and a tectonic and programmatic element. Together these characteristics "turn the constraints of the site into an architectural opportunity, offering a simple and precise museum" with the mathematical and conceptual clarity of ancient [[Greece|Greek]] buildings. The collections of the museum are exhibited on three levels while a fourth middle level houses the auxiliary spaces such as the museum shop, the café and the offices. On the first level of the museum there are the findings of the slopes of the Acropolis. The long and rectangular hall whose floor is sloping, resembles the ascension to the rock. Then, the visitor is found at the large trapezoidal hall which accommodates the archaic findings. On the same floor there are also the artifacts and sculptures from the other Acropolis buildings such as the [[Erechtheum]], the [[Temple of Athena Nike]] and the [[Propylaea]] and findings from Roman and early Christian Athens. Visitors are intended to see the latter during descent in order to keep the chronological order: they will first be directed to the top level, which displays the [[Parthenon]] marbles. The top level of the Museum sits askew on the lower levels to achieve the same cardinal orientation of the ancient temple on the Acropolis. The spacing of the columns of the Parthenon hall is the same as that of the ancient temple, and the use of glass walls on all four exterior walls allows the natural light to illumine the Parthenon marbles as they do on the ancient temple. The 48 columns in the Parthenon hall mark the outline of the ancient temple and form a colonnade for the display of the Parthenon marbles. For ease of viewing, the pediment marbles are displayed at eye level in front of the end columns; the [[Metopes of the Parthenon|metopes]] are displayed on the columns, two per column, but not as high as in the ancient temple; and the [[Parthenon Frieze|frieze]] are displayed behind the metopes, forming a continuous band around the walls of a rectangular space set inside the columns, as in the ancient temple but not as high, again for ease of viewing. From the north side of the Parthenon hall, one can see the ancient temple above on the Acropolis. As the museum is built over an extensive archaeological site, the floor, outside and inside, is often transparent using glass and thus the visitor can see the excavations below. The museum also provides an amphitheatre, a virtual theatre and a hall for temporary exhibitions. ==Controversy== [[File:New Acropolis Museum 5.jpg|thumb|250px|Archaeological site below the main entrance to the museum.]] A controversy erupted over the plans of the new museum and whether it was appropriate to build it on the archaeological site in [[Makrygianni, Athens|Makrygianni]] neighborhood. Another concern was whether a large modern building would fit well into the landscape.{{cite journal|last=Papathanasopoulos|first=G.|date=2002-11-12|title=Aντιπαράθεση για το Nέο Mουσείο Aκρόπολης|journal=[[Kathimerini]]|publisher=news.kathimerini.gr/|issue=Sunday November 10, 2002|language=Greek|url=http://news.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_ell_1_10/11/2002_43463|accessdate=2009-05-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120215004608/http://news.kathimerini.gr/4dcgi/_w_articles_ell_1_10/11/2002_43463|archivedate=February 15, 2012|df=}} In 2007, another controversy erupted over the proposed demolition of two historic buildings. These are in front of the museum, numbers 17 and 19, Dionysiou Areopagitou Street,{{cite news |url=http://www.intbau.org/newsarchive2007.htm#Acropolis161007 |title=Acropolis Now: Call for help to save neoclassical architectural heritage of Athens |year=2007 |accessdate=2008-12-17 |work=International Network for Traditional Building, Architecture and Urbanism |publisher=intbau.org |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090102182849/http://www.intbau.org/newsarchive2007.htm#Acropolis161007 |archivedate=2009-01-02 |df= }} facing the [[Acropolis of Athens|Acropolis]] (see picture, left). Bernard Tschumi has been showing photographic images of the space in front of the museum edited to remove the two buildings and nearby four-story-tall trees. The [[Greece|Greek]] Government has had the two buildings de-listed historically although one is [[Neoclassical architecture|Neo-Classical]] and the other an example of [[Art Deco]] architecture. Protests against the proposed demolition came from international agencies such as [[INTBAU]] and [[ICOMOS]].{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2891014.ece |title=Vangelis Papathanassiou fights Greek gods of demolition |date=2007-11-18 |accessdate=2007-11-23 |work=The Sunday Times |publisher=www.timesonline.co.uk |last=Campbell |first=Matthew | location=London}} ==Awards== * On 13 May 2010, it was awarded the International Association of Lighting Designers (IALD) Award of Excellence and Sustainability.{{cite web|url=http://www.iald.org/file.asp?c=awards\press&f=EB8F4AE1E7474B7CA5B8C155EC790C0D.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=The International Association of Lighting Designers (IALD) |title=Accepting the IALD Award of Excellence and Sustainability Award for the NEW ACROPOLIS MUSEUM was Florence Lam and Vasiliki Malakasi of Arup Lighting}} * On 8 November 2010, the Museum won the [[British Guild of Travel Writers|British Guild of Travel Writers' (BGTW)]] award in Globe category for the Best Worldwide Tourism Project for 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.bgtw.org/tourism-awards-winners-2010.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130615190331/http://www.bgtw.org/tourism-awards-winners-2010.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-06-15 |publisher=British Guild of Travel Writers |title=The winner of the Globe Category (receiving more than 250,000 visitors a year), nominated by Nigel Tisdall, was the new Acropolis Museum in Athens (www.newacropolismuseum.gr/eng), built to replace the old museum which has done an admirable job since 1865, but was short of space. }} * The Museum received 2011 AIA ([[The American Institute of Architects]]) Institute Honor Award for Architecture.{{cite web|url=http://www.aia.org/aiaucmp/groups/aia/documents/html/aiab089705.html|title=2011 Institute Honor Awards for Architecture|work=aia.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130704173023/http://www.aia.org/aiaucmp/groups/aia/documents/html/aiab089705.html|archivedate=2013-07-04|df=}}{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfaKqoEzvwM|title=New Acropolis Museum Receives 2011 AIA Institute Honor Award for Architecture|date=25 May 2011|work=YouTube}} * It was among the six finalists competing for the 2011 [[European Union Prize for Contemporary Architecture|European Union Prize for Contemporary Architecture – the Mies van der Rohe Award]].{{cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/culture/our-programmes-and-actions/doc1103_en.htm|title=Oooops... We didn't find the page you are looking for...|date=12 March 2012|work=europa.eu|access-date=2013-06-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121032232/http://ec.europa.eu/culture/our-programmes-and-actions/doc1103_en.htm|archive-date=2013-11-21|dead-url=yes|df=}} * On Friday 14 September 2012 the Acropolis Museum was awarded for its innovative program of the conservation and the restoration of the [[Caryatids]] by the [[International Institute for Conservation|International Institute for Conservation (IIC)]] in Vienna, with the Keck Award 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/conserving-caryatids|publisher==Acropolis Museum|title=The Acropolis Museum was awarded for this innovative program by the International Institute for Conservation (IIC) in Vienna, with the Keck Award 2012}}{{cite press release|url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/sites/default/files/press_release_keck_award_2012_acropolis_museum.pdf|format=PDF|title=Press release Keck award 2012 Acropolis Museum}} * On 2017, Acropolis museum ranked 8th in the [[TripAdvisor]]'s Travellers Choice Awards of the 25 Best Museums in the world for 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.lifo.gr/now/culture/161032}} ==Other information== [[File:Acropolis Museum - Night.jpg|thumb|A night shot of the Acropolis Museum.]] * The entrance fee to the museum was €1 for the first year and €5 thereafter. * The excavation below ground level continues. The site and process are visible through the ground level glass flooring. The site will be available for visitation once the excavation is complete. * The Acropolis Museum was selected as the motif for a commemorative [[Euro]] coin edition: the €10 Greek [[Euro gold and silver commemorative coins (Greece)#2008 coinage|Acropolis Museum commemorative coin]], minted in 2008 to mark the relocation of the museum. On the obverse is a panoramic view of the Acropolis and the new museum lies at the base. * During the [[International Museum Day]] the museum remains open until late with free entry and many events and activities for its visitors.{{cite web|title=International Museum Day 2016|url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/international-museum-day-2016}} * During the August full moon nights, the museum remains open until late at night and welcomes visitors for free.{{cite web|title=Information about the August full moon in Acropolis Museum.|url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/august-full-moon-1}} Also the same night concerts take place on the museum's courtyard.{{cite web|title=Photos and videos of the Acropolis Museum during the night of August full moon 2013.|url=http://www.athenswalk.net/_/Photos/Pages/Acropolis-concert.html}} * In the first two months since the museum opened, it was visited by 523,540 people (an average of 9,200 a day). Of these, 60 percent were foreign visitors. During the same two-month period, 409,000 hits by unique visitors from 180 countries were recorded by the museum's website.{{cite web|url=http://www.ekathimerini.com/4dcgi/_w_articles_politics_2_28/08/2009_110210|title=In Brief - News - ekathimerini.com|work=ekathimerini.com}} * [[Museum of Applied Arts, Vienna|Museum of Applied Arts/Contemporary Art in Vienna]], have donated (October 2014 - February 2015) to the Acropolis Museum a [[quadriga]] with the goddess [[Nike (mythology)|Nike]] from the collection of [[Theophil Hansen]], the great architect of neoclassical buildings in Greece and central Europe in the 19th century.{{cite web| url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/quadriga-collection-theophil-hansen-acropolis-museum| title=Quadriga from the collection of Theophil Hansen at the Acropolis Museum|website=theacropolismuseum.gr}} * [[Nicholson Museum|The University of Sydney's Nicholson Museum]], have donated (December 2014 - December 2015) to the Acropolis Museum a Lego Acropolis model. The model contains more than 120,000 Lego bricks and took about 300 hours to build by Ryan McNaught.{{cite web|url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/acropolis-lego-bricks-and-lots-fun |title=The Acropolis in Lego bricks and lots of fun! |website=theacropolismuseum.gr |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150611160851/http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/acropolis-lego-bricks-and-lots-fun |archivedate=2015-06-11 }}{{cite web| url=http://www.welcometravel.gr/el/acropolis-museum-receives-lego-model-nicholson-museum/| title=Acropolis Museum receives Lego model from Nicholson Museum|website=welcometravel.gr}} * The [[Spyridon Louis#Breal's Silver Cup|Silver Cup]] designed by [[Michel Bréal]] and awarded to the [[Marathon]] Winner [[Spyridon Louis|Spyros Louis]] at the [[1896 Summer Olympics|first Modern Olympic Games]] (1896), displayed at the Acropolis Museum. The Cup remained to the Acropolis Museum until the completion of the [[Stavros Niarchos Foundation Cultural Center]], where it is now exhibited.{{cite web| url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/historic-silver-cup-awarded-spyros-louis-acropolis-museum| title=Τhe historic Silver Cup awarded to Spyros Louis to the Acropolis Museum|website=theacropolismuseum.gr}} * [[Hermitage Museum]], have donated (March 2016 - October 2016) to the Acropolis Museum, three golden Scythian exhibitions. The three objects were two vessels and a piece of jewelry. These masterpieces of metalworking were crafted by the Greeks at [[Crimea]], that had developed a close relationship with the [[Scythians]].{{cite web| url=http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/scythian-heralds-hermitage-acropolis-museum|title=Scythian heralds from the Hermitage to the Acropolis Museum|website=theacropolismuseum.gr}} * On June 2016, [[Samsung]] inaugurated a digital classroom at the Acropolis Museum. The digital classroom addressed to students of primary and secondary schools. This digital classroom was the first "classroom" which was set up in a Museum in Greece and the fifth in Europe.{{cite web| url=https://news.samsung.com/global/next-station-of-digital-education-the-acropolis-museum|title=Next Station of Digital Education: The Acropolis Museum|website=samsung}} * The [[US President]] [[Barack Obama]] visited the Acropolis museum during his visit at Athens (November 15–16, 2016).{{cite news|last1=Becatoros|first1=Elena|last2=Lederman|first2=Josh|title=Obama tours ancient Greek Acropolis|url=http://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/obama-to-tour-ancient-greek-acropolis/|accessdate=November 16, 2016|agency=[[Associated Press]]|via=''[[The Seattle Times]]''|date=November 15, 2016}}{{cite news |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3941510/Next-time-ll-just-tourist-foreign-visit-President-Barack-Obama-feels-hand-history-Greece.html |title='The only way forward is democracy... even though you don't always win!' Obama tries to look on the bright side in the wake of Trump's election victory as he gives a speech in the birthplace of democracy |first1=Chris |last1=Summers |date=November 16, 2016 |publisher=''[[The Daily Mail]]'' |archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20161116202430/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article%2D3941510/Next%2Dtime%2Dll%2Djust%2Dtourist%2Dforeign%2Dvisit%2DPresident%2DBarack%2DObama%2Dfeels%2Dhand%2Dhistory%2DGreece.html |archive-date=November 16, 2016}} * On March 24 - October 31, 2017, [[Documenta 14]], the fourteenth edition of the art exhibition [[documenta]] takes place at the Acropolis Museum.[http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/en/content/robert-wilson-acropolis-museum Robert Wilson at the Acropolis Museum] ==Gallery==
