AD-2.jpg|Goddess Nike (1st to 3rd century AD) File:Tiberius Julius Sauromates II.jpg|Bust of [[Tiberius Julius Sauromates II]] File:EHGritaly 120304-08 (Acropolis Museum 2).JPG|Archaeological site below the main entrance to the museum
==See also== *[[Old Acropolis Museum]], now closed and scheduled to house workshops for the ongoing [http://www.ysma.gr/en/ Acropolis Restoration Project] *[[Elgin Marbles]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== * {{cite book | last = Tschumi | first = Bernard | last2 = Pandermalis | first2 = Dimitrios | last3 = Aesopos | first3 = Yannis | last4 = Rutten | first4 = Joel | title = The New Acropolis Museum | publisher = Skira Rizzoli | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-0847834198 }} * {{cite book | last = Tschumi | first = Bernard | title = New Acropolis Museum | publisher = Ediciones Poligrafa | year = 2010 | isbn = 978-8434312340 }} ==External links== {{commons category|Acropolis Museum}} {{commons category|Acropolis New Museum Building}} *[http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr Official site] *[http://www.parthenonfrieze.gr The Parthenon frieze]. *[http://www.theacropolismuseum.gr/peploforos/ Color the Peplos Kore]. *[http://www.acropolis-athena.gr/ Athena, Goddess of the Acropolis]. *[https://www.google.com/culturalinstitute/collection/acropolis-museum?projectId=art-project Google Art Project]. *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130411033728/http://www.latsis-foundation.org/megazine/publish/ebook.php?book=39&preloader=1 Acropolis Museum - Ebook by Latsis Foundation] *[http://www.theliberal.co.uk/artsandculture/sandis-acropolis.html The New Acropolis by C. Sandis] * [http://www.museumchick.com/museum-chick/2010/10/new-acropolis-museum-athens.html A visitors look at the Acropolis Museum] * [http://www.unrv.com/museum/acropolis-museum.php Review of the Acropolis Museum at UNRV.com] ===Videos=== * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KfaKqoEzvwM New Acropolis Museum Receives 2011 AIA Institute Honor Award for Architecture] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4_PwdyEnwnE A short visit to the Acropolis Museum ] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IaGdJrbOKes New Acropolis Museum, Athens - Opening Ceremony Video Projections] {{Museums in Athens}} {{Landmarks in Athens}} {{Acropolis of Athens}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Acropolis of Athens|Museum, new]] [[Category:Ancient Greek culture]] [[Category:Archaeological museums in Athens]] [[Category:Greek culture]] [[Category:Landmarks in Athens]] [[Category:Museums established in 2008]] [[Category:Museums in Athens]] [[Category:Museums of ancient Greece]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Greece]] [[Category:Acropolis Museum| ]] [[Category:Modernist architecture in Greece]]

revision.comment: Fixed instance in which source Dr. Vail Reese is incorrectly referred to as "Dr. pool Reese" in body text, even though the correct name was given in the citation
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} The depiction of '''albinism in popular culture''', especially the portrayal of people with [[albinism]] in film and fiction, has been asserted by albinism organizations and others to be largely negative and has raised concerns that it reinforces, or even engenders, societal prejudice and discrimination against such people.<ref name="noah1">[http://www.albinism.org/pressRelease/pressRelease2005-01-06.html "'Evil Albino' missing from 2004 movies. Will ''The Da Vinci Code'' revive the cliché?"], The National Organization for Albinism and Hypopigmentation, 6 January 2005; accessed 15 December 2006</ref> This trend is sometimes referred to as the ''"evil albino" [[plot device]]''.<ref name="noah1" />
The "evil albino" [[stereotype]] or [[stock character]] is a [[villain]] in [[fiction]] who is depicted as being albinistic (or displaying physical traits usually associated with albinism, even if the term is not used), with the specific and obvious purpose of distinguishing the villain in question from the heroes by means of appearance.<ref name="noah1" /><ref name="skinema4">[http://www.skinema.com/Evil3Albin1.html "Beyond the pale: Hollywood's unwritten rules for characters with albinism"], ''Skinema: Dermatology in the Cinema'', Dr. Vail Reese; accessed 15 December 2006</ref> Traits of albinism commonly associated with the evil albino stereotype include pale skin, platinum blonde hair, and blue or pink-to-red eyes. Notably absent from most depictions is impaired vision, which is experienced by most real people with albinism.<ref name="noah1" /><ref name="skinema1">[http://www.skinema.com/SpotMediaMatrix1.html "Furor Over ''The Matrix: Reloaded''"], ''Skinema: Dermatology in the Cinema'', Dr. Vail Reese; accessed 15 December 2006</ref><ref name="skinema2">[http://www.skinema.com/SpotMediaMatrix2.html "Furor Over ''The Matrix: Reloaded'' — Continued"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141110151305/http://www.skinema.com/SpotMediaMatrix2.html |date=10 November 2014 }}, ''Skinema: Dermatology in the Cinema'', Dr. Vail Reese; accessed 15 December 2006</ref>
The stereotype has become sufficiently well-recognized to attract satire and to be considered a [[cliché]]. In response to the "albino gunmen" characters in ''[[The Da Vinci Code (film)|The Da Vinci Code]]'' and ''[[The Matrix Reloaded]]'', albinistic actor Dennis Hurley wrote, produced and starred in a [[short film]] parody, ''[[The Albino Code]]'', playing up the stereotypes, illustrating a typical example of real-world prejudice, and pointing out that the vision problems associated with albinism would make a successful career as a hitman highly improbable. In ''[[The Big Over Easy]]'', author [[Jasper Fforde]] includes an "albino community" protest against albino bias among his fictional news clippings, most of which satirize stock characters and hackneyed plot devices. ''Chicago Tribune'' movie reviewer Mark Caro says of this character type that it is someone "who looks albino and thus, in movie shorthand, must be vicious".<ref name="CTribCaro">[http://metromix.chicagotribune.com/movies/mmx-031222movies-review-mc-coldmountain,0,7819885.story "Movie review: ''Cold Mountain''"]; Caro, Mark; ''Chicago Tribune'' (online edition), date unspecified; accessed 13 March 2007</ref> The [[National Organization for Albinism and Hypopigmentation]] (NOAH) has stated that there were a total of sixty-eight films from 1960 to 2006 featuring an "evil albino".<ref name="CNN-DVC">[http://www.cnn.com/2006/SHOWBIZ/Movies/05/17/film.davinci.protests/index.html "Early viewers pan ''Da Vinci Code'': Film's release also provokes widespread protests"]; no by-line; ''CNN.com'' "Entertainment" section / ''Associated Press Newswire'', 17 May 2006; accessed 13 March 2007</ref>
Conversely, a number of real people with albinism have risen to fame {{crossref|printworthy=y|(see {{section link||Notable people with albinism}}, below}}, especially in popular music and fashion modeling (though, as in [[#autumn|the case of the Winter brothers]], may themselves be the subject of "evil albino" parody). Albino animals capture public imagination and wonder as zoo attractions, and even in the wild can attract popular, positive attention {{crossref|printworthy=y|(see {{section link||Notable albino animals}}, below}}.
==History of the "evil albino" stereotype== The "evil albino" stereotype may also have its roots in [[Neolithic]] [[Eastern Europe]], where some cultures depicted [[Death (personification)|Death]] as a pallid woman with light hair.<ref>''The Language of the Goddess'', [[Marija Gimbutas]], 1989, page 198</ref> Fear of [[vampires]] and other legendary [[undead]] with a deathly [[pallor]], especially in European folklore, could also have contributed to albino bias. The phenomenon may also have been influenced by attitudes towards people with albinism in Africa or Jamaica, where those with that condition are sometimes regarded as cursed or magical {{crossref|printworthy=y|(see {{section link||Folklore, urban legends and myths}}, below)}}. [[Dermatology|Dermatologist]] Dr. Vail Reese theorizes that albino bias may be part of a broader Hollywood pattern of equating or at least linking skin disorders and appearance problems with villainy.<ref name="skinema3">[http://www.skinema.com/Evil1Scars.html "Most movies that feature skin disease use it to represent evil"], ''Skinema: Dermatology in the Cinema'', Dr. Vail Reese; accessed 15 December 2006</ref>
Another explanation may be sought in respective ideals of ugliness — most "evil albinos" appear in works of fiction from the West. In fiction from Japan, where ideals call for as pale skin as possible, characters with albinism or associated traits are more frequently sympathetic<ref name="LunaEterna1">[http://www.lunaeterna.net/popcult/anime_manga.htm "Japanese Anime and Manga"] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20040129143332/http://www.lunaeterna.net/popcult/anime_manga.htm |date=29 January 2004 }}, ''Albinism in Popular Culture'', by Luna Eterna, 1997–2006; accessed 8 January 2007</ref> than in American and British fiction.<ref name="LunaEterna2">[http://www.lunaeterna.net/popcult/comics_eng.htm "American and British Comics"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061116234936/http://www.lunaeterna.net/popcult/comics_eng.htm |date=16 November 2006 }}, ''Albinism in Popular Culture'', by Luna Eterna, 1997–2006; accessed 8 January 2007</ref> This is not to say that [[Japanese popular culture]] has not depicted "evil albinos". However, such characters in Japanese fiction are often ''[[bishōnen]]'' or ''[[bishōjo]]'' whose beautiful appearance gives contrast to their evil character. Use of albinistic features to indicate villains in Hollywood films appears to have begun in the 1960s, and may be related to the popularity of tanning (and thus a decrease in pale skin being seen as attractive) in this period.<ref name="skinema4" />
One of the oldest perceived literary examples of albino bias was [[H. G. Wells]]'s depiction of the main character in his 1897 science-fiction novel ''[[The Invisible Man]]'', who was able to become invisible using his scientific discoveries only because he already lacked natural pigmentation; aberrant even before his experimentation, he subsequently became completely deranged.
Albino bias is also alleged in modern times. For example, the 2003 Warner Bros movie ''The Matrix Reloaded'' featured two sociopathic characters with pale skin and white hair frequently interpreted to be albinos despite studio declarations that they are not.<ref name="skinema2" /> Positive depictions of albinos in mass culture are rarer, though one example is the 1995 film ''[[Powder (film)|Powder]]'' which depicts an exceptionally gifted albinistic youth and the cruelty he endures from "normal" people because of his differences. In recent years, the National Organization for Albinism and Hypopigmentation (NOAH) has spoken out<ref name="noah1" /> against albino bias in the United States. Albinistic actor Michael C. Bowman, of ''[[Me, Myself and Irene]]'', has said, "Kids all over this country are being affected in a very negative and harmful way because of the sloppiness and laziness of a writer in Hollywood."<ref name="skinema2" />
==Albinism and fiction== {{hatnote|1=Note: These lists do {{em|not}} include characters whose appearance is reminiscent of albininism, but for reasons other than actual albinism. These include but are not limited to aliens, the undead, magical beings, unusually-colored anime/manga characters, etc. An exception is characters commonly perceived to be albinistic.<!--"Commonly perceived" must be demonstrated by reliable sources per [[WP:RS]] on a case-by-case basis.-->}} <!--Examples of characters already removed, and which will be deleted if added again without corroboration from reliable sources: * Alien races, as in "Stargate: Atlantis", ''I Come in Peace", and "Star Wars: Episode II" * Nosferatu and other flimic vampires; Solomon Grundy from "Green Lantern"; and other "living-dead" * Various anime/manga and game characters, like Albedo Piazzolla and Wilhelm in "Xenosaga", Ramirez/Zelos in "Skies of Arcadia"; Rei Ayanami in "Neon Genesis Evangelion" (Rei is said by one NON-AUTHORITATIVE source to be an albino, but the story itself says her appearance is the result of human-alien crossbreeding); Keel Lorenz also from "Evangelion" who has white hair and poor vision simply because he is very old; Yukishiro Enishi in "Rurouni Kenshin" (turned pale by grief); and many other such chars. with white or off-white hair and sometimes even red eyes, but normal skin tone, such as Sephiroth in "Final Fantasy VII" and Dark Bakura. * Zao, the genetically "bleached" Asian in "Die Another Day"; Geralt of Rivia in "The Witcher" series, a cat-eyed magical mutant of elvish descent. * Superhero mutants like La Lunatica in "X-Men 2099", and Punk Rocket in "Teen Titans" Adding such characters because you think they "might" be albinos or "should" be considered albinos is disallowed [[WP:OR|original research]]. --> A number of movies, books and other works have been criticized<ref name="noah1" /><ref name="skinema4" /><ref name="skinema1" /> for '''albino bias''', as they associate the uncommon features of albinistic people (pale skin, white hair, and unpigmented eyes) with danger, terror, or criminality. Less frequently they are depicted as the harmless butt of jokes and ridicule, as maladjusted and undersocialized, or as "[[freak]]s".<ref name="skinema4" /><ref name="skinema5">[http://www.skinema.com/Evil4Albin2.html "Book two of Hollywood's rules of albinism"], ''Skinema: Dermatology in the Cinema'', Dr. Vail Reese.</ref> They may also actually be portrayed positively, even heroically – a more recent counter-trend.{{Citation needed|date=March 2007}} In the 2012 Canadian movie [[war witch]] (rebelle) by Kim Nguyen, telling the story of a runaway child soldier in West Africa and an albino boy played by [[Serge Kanyinda]], albinos play an important role. The movie portrays an albino community.
===Negatively portrayed characters {{anchor|Villains}}=== {{Multiple image|direction=vertical|align=right|image1=Edgar Winter 1 - 1974.jpg|image2=Johnny Winter.jpg|width=150|caption2=Brothers [[Edgar Winter|Edgar]] and [[Johnny Winter]], rock musicians with albinism subject to parody as "evil albinos" in a comic book.}} <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** -->
The most common depiction of people with albinism in fiction is that of the inimical, violent villain, especially the [[Contract killing|hitman]], [[Assassination|assassin]], [[Psychopathy|sociopath]] or [[crime boss]].<ref name="skinema4" /><ref name="skinema1" /><ref name="skinema2" /><ref name="skinema5" />
* "The Family", a cult of plague survivors are the antagonist in the film ''[[The Omega Man]]'' (1971). * [[List of The Da Vinci Code characters#Silas|Silas]], in the book ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'' (2003) by [[Dan Brown]], (played by [[Paul Bettany]] in the 2006 [[The Da Vinci Code|film adaptation]]), is described as being albinistic. He is a religious fanatic and an assassin who murders several people, although he repents at the end of the book, praying to God for mercy and forgiveness. Critics have called the portrayal "damning", "hateful", and "cruelly stereotypical".<ref name="Softpedia1">[http://news.softpedia.com/news/The-Da-Vinci-Code-Albinos-Murderer-Depiction-Was-Slammed-19949.shtml "''The Da Vinci Code'' Albinos[sic] Murderer Depiction Was Slammed"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070418162901/http://news.softpedia.com/news/The-Da-Vinci-Code-Albinos-Murderer-Depiction-Was-Slammed-19949.shtml |date=18 April 2007 }}; Gheorghe, Adina; ''Softpedia Reviews'', 20 March 2006; accessed 13 March 2007</ref> In defense, author Brown has pointed out that "Silas's skin color has nothing to do with his violent nature – he is driven to violence by others' cruelty... not by anything inherent in his physiology" and that he believes "the novel's portrayal of Silas is a compassionate exploration of how difficult albinism can be – especially for young people – and how cruelly societies can ostracize those of us who look different", going on to say he considers Silas to be the most sympathetic character in the story.<ref name="Silas">[http://www.danbrown.com/novels/davinci_code/faqs.html Dan Brown's FAQ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116181432/http://www.danbrown.com/novels/davinci_code/faqs.html |date=16 January 2009 }} Retrieved on 21 April 2007.</ref> * "[[Twins (The Matrix)|The Twins]]" (played by Adrian and Neil Rayment), in ''[[The Matrix Reloaded]]'' (2003)<ref name="imdbmatrixr">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0234215/ "The Matrix Reloaded"], at IMDb</ref> are considered by detractors<ref name="skinema1" /> to be the highest-profile case of "evil albino" bias to date, though said by producers<ref name="skinema2" /> to not be intended to be taken as actually albinistic. * {{Anchor|autumn|Autumn}}Edgar and Johnny Autumn, in four 1995 issues of the ''[[Jonah Hex]]'' comic book, are mutant villain brothers for the main character to fight. They were thinly-disguised caricatures of real-life albinistic musician brothers, Edgar and Johnny Winter ''(see image, right)'', who filed an unsuccessful lawsuit (''Edgar Winter et al. v. DC Comics et al.'').<ref name="MetNewsEnt1">[http://www.metnews.com/articles/wint062002.htm "C.A. Revives Rock Stars’ Suit Over Use of Their Personae"], ''Metropolitan News-Enterprise'', 20 June 2002; accessed 15 December 2006.</ref> A spokesperson for Johnny Winter characterized the depiction as "picking fun at them for being albinos", while a [[DC Comics]] representative claimed that the characters were an homage.<ref name="AP 2006">{{Cite news |url= http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=11551 <!--Among others.--> |title=Comic-book villains modeled on brothers ruled protected speech |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |work=AP Newswire |location=Washington, D.C. |agency=[[Associated Press]] |date=3 March 2006 |access-date=17 December 2009 |archive-url= http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20041213123707/http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=11551 |archive-date=13 December 2004 |deadurl=no}}</ref> * [[Griffin (The Invisible Man)|Griffin]], the main character of ''[[The Invisible Man]]'' (1897) by [[H. G. Wells]] is of questionable sanity and a thief by nature, obsessed with colour and pigmentation due to his albinism. The text of Wells's novel implies that Griffin's invisibility formula works on him (and a white cat in an early experiment) only ''because'' of albinism. <small>''(See [[The Invisible Man|main article]] for sources.)''</small> *Francis Davey, the vicar of Altarnun in [[Daphne du Maurier]]'s novel "[[Jamaica Inn]]" is an albino whose status as a 'freak of nature' is explicitly linked to his rejection of conventional morality and hence his villainous actions including murder. * Samuel Aboah from ''[[The X-Files]]'' episode "Teliko". He was a [[Burkina Faso|Burkinabé]] immigrant who, lacking a pituitary gland, harvested them from other African or African-American men to restore his skin tone. He is compared unfavourably to a vampire like creature from West African folklore (the eponymous Teliko) by a Burkinabé ambassador. He is depicted as a merciless killer with a seemingly inhuman ability to squeeze into small spaces (a la previous X-Files villain [[Eugene Victor Tooms]]) * "Snow" (played by [[Billy Drago]]), in ''[[Vamp (film)|Vamp]]'' (1986)<ref name="imdbvamp">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092147/ ''Vamp''], at IMDb</ref> is the violently-inclined leader of a street gang composed of albinistic people and others with appearance problems. He meets a violent end.<ref name="skinema4" /> * Joseph (played by [[Jake Busey]], son of Gary Busey; see next entry), in ''[[Contact (1997 American film)|Contact]]'' (1997)<ref name="imdbcontact">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0118884/ "Contact"], at IMDb</ref> is a religious extremist turned suicide-bomber.<ref name="skinema2" /> * Mr. Joshua (played by [[Gary Busey]]), in ''[[Lethal Weapon]]'' (1987)<ref name="imdblw1">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093409/ "Lethal Weapon"], at IMDb.</ref> is a seemingly psychopathic hit man.<ref name="skinema4" /> He was specifically referred to as "albino" in the film. * Bosie (played by Charlie Hunnam),<ref name="imdbhunnam">[https://www.imdb.com/gallery/ss/0159365/Ss/0159365/9042.jpg.html?path=pgallery&path_key=Hunnam,%20Charlie "Images of Charlie Hunnam"], IMDb</ref> in ''[[Cold Mountain (film)|Cold Mountain]]'' (2003)<ref name="imdbcoldmtn">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0159365/ "Cold Mountain"], at IMDb.</ref> is a U.S. Civil War-era "sneering albino killer ...[who] seems to have wandered in from a ''Lethal Weapon'' movie" — Ty Burr, ''Boston Globe'' review.<ref name="skinema4" /><ref name="BGlobeBurr">[http://www.boston.com/movies/display?display=movie&id=4225 "Cold Mountain Movie Review: Moving 'Mountain'"]; Burr, Ty; ''Boston Globe'' (online edition), 25 December 2003; accessed 13 March 2007</ref> * "Bad Bob" (played by Stacy Keach) in ''[[The Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean]]'' (1972) * "Dragon" (played by Thayer David) in ''[[The Eiger Sanction (film)|The Eiger Sanction]]'' (1975)<ref name="imdbeiger">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0072926/ "The Eiger Sanction"], at IMDb</ref> is an underworld kingpin also described as being unable to stand light and requiring frequent blood transfusions. * "The Albino" (played by Mel Smith), in ''[[The Princess Bride]]'' (1987)<ref name="imdbpbride">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0093779/ "The Princess Bride"], at IMDb.</ref> is an [[Igor (fictional character)|Igor]]-like [[henchman]] and torturer, depicted as diseased, with visible sores.<ref name="skinema4" /> * "Albino" (played by the genuinely albinistic [[Victor Varnado]]), in ''[[End of Days (film)|End of Days]]'' (1999)<ref name="imdbeofd">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0146675/ "End of days"], at IMDb</ref> is a menacing "servant of [[Satan in popular culture|Satan]]" who meets a grisly death.<ref name="skinema4" /> * "Whitey" Jackson a.k.a. "The Albino" (played by [[William Frankfather]]), in ''[[Foul Play (1978 film)|Foul Play]]'' (1978)<ref name="imdbfoulplay78">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0077578/ "Foul Play (1978)"], at IMDb</ref> is another heavily armed killer, this time in a comedy.<ref name="skinema4" /> * "[[Tombstone (comics)|Tombstone]]", in the ''[[Spider-Man]]'' comics is an African-American with albinism. He is a mob hitman. <small>''(See [[Tombstone (comics)|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * "[[Tobias Whale]]" a [[DC Comics]] [[African-American]] albinistic [[mobster]] whose villainy induces character Jefferson Pierce to become the superhero "[[Black Lightning]]". <small>''(See [[Tobias Whale|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * Moke (played by [[Dar Robinson]]), in ''[[Stick (film)|Stick]]'' (1985)<ref name="imdbstick">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0090073/ "Stick"], at IMDb.</ref> is a ruthless criminal, who likes to shoot people in the back<ref name="skinema4" /><ref name="skinema2" /> * [[Judge Holden]], in [[Cormac McCarthy]]'s ''[[Blood Meridian]]'' (published 1985; {{ISBN|0-394-54482-X}}). In McCarthy's novel, Holden is a wanton mass-murderer. There is no historical evidence to suggest that the non-fictional Holden was albinistic. <small>''(See [[Judge Holden|main article]] for further sources.)''</small> * "Albino" (played by Warrick Grier), in ''[[Freefall (1994 film)|Freefall]]'' (1994)<ref name="imdbfreefall">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109840/ "Freefall"], at IMDb.</ref> is a menacing figure who drugs the film's heroine.<ref name="skinema4" /> * Mark Purayah (Mark II) and Mark Parchezzi (Mark III) ("the Albinos"), in ''[[Hitman: Blood Money]]'' (released 2005)<ref name="imdbhitmanbm">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0433390/ "Hitman: Blood Money (VG)"], at IMDb.</ref> are clones of an unseen Mark I, and all are assassins. <small>''(See [[Hitman: Blood Money|main article]] for further sources.)''</small> * [[Otis B. Driftwood]] (played by [[Bill Moseley]]), in ''[[House of 1000 Corpses]]'' (2003).<ref name="imdbho1000c">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0251736/ "House of 1000 Corpses"], at IMDb</ref> leads a clan of psychopathic backwoods serial killers. Despite being played by the same actor, in the sequel ''[[The Devil's Rejects]]'' (2005)<ref name="imdbdevilrej">[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0395584/ "The Devil's Rejects"], at IMDb</ref> he has a normal skin tone. <small>''(See [[Otis B. Driftwood|main article]] for further sources.)''</small> * "The Albino" in ''[[The Albino's Dancer]]'', a "[[Time Hunter]]" novella; the character is a [[mobster]].<small>''(See [[The Albino's Dancer|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * "The Albino" (played by [[Bill Bolender]]) from the ''[[Star Trek: Deep Space Nine]]'' episode "[[Blood Oath (DS9 episode)|Blood Oath]]", who is a dishonorable Klingon warrior and murderer. <small>''(See [[Blood Oath (DS9 episode)|main article]] for further sources.)''</small> * Dr. Robert Kirkland "Kirk" Langström, also known as the [[Man-Bat]], is depicted as being albinistic in the television series ''[[The Batman (TV series)|The Batman]]'' (which also depicts him as more villainous than other versions of the character).<ref name="Batman1">{{cite episode |title=The Man Who Would Be Bat |series=[[The Batman (TV series)|The Batman]] |credits=Thomas Pugsley and Greg Klein (writers) |airdate=30 October 2004 |season=1 |number=4}}</ref> Langström's "Man-Bat" form is also depicted as being albino.<small>''(See [[Man-Bat|main article]] for further sources.)''</small> * Kobra, an albinistic [[Outlaw motorcycle club|biker]] in [[Robert R. McCammon]]'s 1981 novel ''[[They Thirst]]'' who is depicted as sadistic and violent. He eventually becomes a commander of an army of [[vampire]]s besieging Los Angeles (but was albinistic before becoming a vampire).<small>''(See [[They Thirst|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * [[Monsieur Zenith]], a [[Pulp magazine|pulp fiction]] villain in the "[[Sexton Blake]]" series by Anthony Skene. Zenith is a world-weary [[gentleman thief]] who uses [[opium]], commits crimes, and feuds with Blake simply to relieve his ennui. * The clairvoyant albino [[Juni Swan]] in [[Darren Shan]]'s "[[The Demonata]]" series is characterized by her deceptive and sadistic nature as well as her exceptional beauty. However, in ''[[Death's Shadow (novel)|Death's Shadow]]'', the seventh book of the series, she appears as a hideously deformed monster. * "Helter Skelter", a mysterious assassin seen in the opening cutscene of the video game ''[[No More Heroes (video game)|No More Heroes]]'' * Bigboy, the sadistic, ruthless chief of the prison guards in the Stephen Hunter novel ''Pale Horse Coming.'' * Jei Farfarello, a sadistic/masochistic member of a group of assassins named "Schwarz" in the anime ''[[Weiß Kreuz]]''. He is portrayed as a one-eyed, heavily scarred and clinically insane killer. * Olivia Presteign, the daughter of a powerful business man in [[Alfred Bester]]'s [[The Stars My Destination]], is responsible for numerous homicides along with various other crimes. Her albinism renders her blind to the normal spectrum of light visible to humans, but she is able to see the infrared spectrum. * The anime/manga Deadman Wonderland features two albinos named Chan and En as bodyguards to the main antagonist of the series, the director of Deadman Wonderland named Hagire Rinichirou. They are twin brother and sister, and are incredibly loyal to Hagire, seeing him as a father figure and killing people who merely insult him. There is also a third albino, one of the main characters, named Shiro, who appears an innocent and complacent young girl, but has a cruel and psychopathic alter ego knows as the Wretched Egg, which is Hagire's lifetime obsession. * The Mark clones in [[Hitman: Blood Money]] are genetically-created assassins from the rival organization The Foundation. * Shadow Prove from Bakugan New Vestroia is most probably albino. He often laughs at other peoples problems and tries to annoy but hates being insulted by Mylene, his companion. He is part of the evil organisation Vexos. ;Animals and other non-humanoid characters *In ''[[Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs]]'', the main [[antagonist]], named Rudy, is a huge albino ''[[Baryonyx]]''. Unlike most other dinosaurs in the film, he is depicted as vicious, vindictive and entirely inimical. The filmmakers explicitly stated that his albinism is a reference to [[Moby Dick]] and other pale fictional antagonists.<ref name="IADotD">{{Cite video |title=[[Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs]] |time=1:16:15 |people=[[Carlos Saldanha|Saldanha, Carols]] (dir.) |medium=[[DVD]], "Filmmaker Commentary" audio track |location=[[Century City, California]] |publisher=[[20th Century Fox]] |display-authors=etal}} Audio commentary initially says character based on ''Baryonyx'', someone else said ''[[Suchomimus]]''; both are [[spinosaurs]].</ref> *The Megalodon in Steve Alten's novel ''[[Meg: A Novel of Deep Terror]]'', hunted by the main characters, is depicted as albino.{{Clarify|date=September 2010|reason=In what way is this a negative portrayal?}} * The Banes from [[Suzanne Collins]]'s ''[[The Underland Chronicles]]'' novel series. An albino gnawer (giant, talking rat). Born once every few hundred years, they are always insane, tyrannical, and far larger than even the other gnawers. The only one featured in the series is Pearlpelt. He is, however, an exception, as all the ''Underland'' humans are albinos, and they are generally portrayed favorably, with varying personalities. {{crossref|(See also ''Underland'' humans, below.)}}
===Subjects of ridicule and "freaks"=== {{Refimprove section|date=November 2009}} {{See also|#Film and television coverage of discrimination against albinism}} In the last few decades, there has been an increase in the number albinistic characters who are mocked (sometimes by the actual works in which they appear, an instance of albino bias itself, and sometimes by other characters in a way that highlights albino bias). <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** --> * "Powder", the eponymous character in the movie ''[[Powder (film)|Powder]]''. The name can be seen as mocking or derogatory; however the depiction can be seen as positive in its portrayal of the effects of bias against those with albinism.<ref name="skinema5" /> * Autumn Lynn Henderson, the sister of the protagonist in "Mercy Among the Children" by [[David Adams Richards]]. Already an outcast in their small New Brunswick town because of their father's reputation, she is further alienated during her adolescence due to her albinism. Her brother (and protagonist) Lyle tries to make Autumn's life easier by purchasing a wig and contact lenses for her, but it helps very little in the treatment of her by the other children. *Casper, a.k.a. "Whitey" or "Q-Tip"<ref name="skinema2" /> (played by [[Michael Bowman]]), in ''[[Me, Myself & Irene]]'' (2000).<ref name="skinema4" /> His [[Casper the Friendly Ghost|alleged real name is as mocking]] as his nicknames. He is the subject of a good deal of ridicule, which may be accurately representative of the casual discrimination that people with albinism are often made to suffer, and is accurately depicted as having impaired vision, and is a vital friend of the main characters. The genuinely albinistic actor "somewhat regrets" taking the role: "I worried that it was sending the wrong message."<ref name="skinema2" /> * Cee-Cee, a character in "The Mediator" novel series by [[Meg Cabot]], is ridiculed by her classmates. Generally portrayed fairly accurately as a person with albinism, wearing protective clothing, sunscreen, hats, and sunglasses outdoors, though said to have purplish irises even though that is rare. While described supportively, as intelligent. On the other hand, Cee-Cee's aunt, who also has albinism, reads [[tarot cards]] and speaks with the dead. * Harold Kline, in ''Ghost Boy'', a novel by [[Iain Lawrence]], is an albinistic youth who ran away from home and ended up working in the circus with the other "freaks", as people called them. His portrayal is supportive, but the "freak" label is not, even if accurately depicting biased attitudes. * The hermaphrodite in [[Federico Fellini]]'s ''[[Fellini Satyricon]]''.<ref name="skinema4" /> <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** -->
===Neutrally or ambiguously portrayed characters=== <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** --> {{Refimprove section|date=November 2009}} Neutral or at least morally uncertain depictions of persons with albinism are also somewhat common in literature and film, as anti-heroes, morally confused characters, or simply incidentally.
* [[Elric of Melniboné]], the main character of an eponymous series of fantasy novels and short stories by [[Michael Moorcock]] that began in 1961 with "The Dreaming City". Elric is described as handsome and intelligent, but physically weak without the aid of drugs and magic. In the book ''Stormbringer'', Elric's final battle saw him heroically defeating the evil forces of Chaos to become the last person alive before the rebirth of humankind. The author stated in 2004 that he had received no complaints with regards to his treatment of albinism since "after all, Elric is a hero (if somewhat flawed)".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.multiverse.org/fora/showthread.php?t=538 |title=Elric & Albinism. - Moorcock's Miscellany |publisher=Multiverse.org |date= |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717055216/http://www.multiverse.org/fora/showthread.php?t=538 |archivedate=17 July 2011 }}</ref> However, Elric also frequently murders in cold blood and is classified by some reviewers/critics as an anti-hero, even a protagonist–villain.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.revolutionsf.com/article.php?id=4045 |first=Joe |last=Crowe |title=''Elric: Stealer of Souls'' Reviewed |work=Revolution Science Fiction |location=[[Drums, Pennsylvania]] |publisher=Revolution Web Development |date=25 April 2008 |access-date=16 December 2009 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20091129223826/http://www.revolutionsf.com/article.php?id=4045 |archive-date=29 November 2009 |dead-url=no}}</ref> Elric was based in part on the aforementioned M. Zenith. <small>''(See [[Elric of Melniboné|main article]] for further sources.)''</small> * "Snow", an albinistic psychic who achieves a messianic following, has his story told in ''[[Snow (Spock's Beard album)|Snow]]'', a [[concept album]] by [[progressive rock]] band [[Spock's Beard]]. The portrayal is ambiguous and unrealistic, and the character has a stereotypical moniker. * "U.V.", played by non-albinistic actor [[Chad E. Donella]], in the film ''[[Disturbing Behavior]]''. He is not a villain, but a [[Stoner (cannabis)|stoner]] with a stereotypical nickname that refers to his skin sensitivity, while on the other hand has a clever sense of humor, is "hip", and is well-accepted by his friends.<ref name="skinema4" /> <small>''(See [[Disturbing Behavior|main article]] for additional sources.)''</small> * "The bride" (played by the genuinely albinistic<ref name="skinema6">[http://www.skinema.com/Real3Genetic.html "Realistic Characters with Genetic Conditions"], ''Skinema: Dermatology in the Cinema'', Dr. Vail Reese; accessed 15 December 2006</ref> Diane Costa), in ''[[Nobody's Fool (1986 film)|Nobody's Fool]]'' (1986)<ref name="imdbfool">[http://imdb.com/title/tt0091642/fullcredits#cast "Full cast and crew for ''Nobody's Fool'' (1986)"], at IMDb</ref> Depicted accurately, though possibly mostly for comedic effect, as requiring sunglasses under her veil at her outdoor wedding, and mocked behind her back as having landed a husband out of pity, but shown as engaging in a normal societal role.<ref name="skinema6" /> * Snowdie McLain, an albinistic woman, is a central character in Eudora Welty's "[[The Golden Apples]]", a book of connected stories set in Mississippi. Other characters sometimes link Snowdie's albinism to her reserved manner or her perceived helplessness.{{Clarify|date=March 2008}}<!--None of this exposition tells us much about the character. How is the portrayal non-positive enough that it is in the neutral/ambiguous section?--> * [[Hinoto|Princess Hinoto]], in the [[X (manga)|''X'' manga and TV series and ''X-1999'' movie]]. While a heroine in the original comics and movie, she becomes a villain in the follow-up television series. Has red eyes in some episodes, purplish in others. Accurately portrayed as having vision problems, but also given deaf-muteness, lameness, and psychic powers.<ref name="LunaEterna1" /> * "Whitey" (played by [[Robert Englund]]), in ''[[Buster and Billie]]''. He dyes his hair black, but is known by his nickname, which he wears on his hat.<ref name="skinema4" /> * The detective, in ''What's the Worst that Could Happen?''<!-- (197?)-->. Like the villain in ''Foul Play'', he wears all-white suits.<ref name="skinema4" /> * Olympia Binewski, an albinistic, [[Alopecia totalis|bald]], [[Kyphosis|hunchbacked]] [[Dwarfism|dwarf]], from the 1989 novel ''[[Geek Love]]'' by [[Katherine Dunn]]. "Oly" is the narrator of the story, and as part of a family intentionally bred for defects for traveling carnival show purposes is no more or less "freakish" than the rest of the major characters; her albinism appears simply to have been selected at random by the author as a genetic abnormality to add to the list. ''(See [[Geek Love|main article]] for sources and further detail.)''{{Clarify|date=September 2007}}<!--This was originally filed under the heroic/positive section. What is heroic or positive about this portrayal? The [[Geek Love]] article does not give any hint, and simply being the main character doesn't necessarily mean it is positive; cf. ''[[The Jackal]]'' for a (non-albinistic) example.--> *Cielle, a minor character in the flash animation film ''[[Broken Saints]]'', is an albinistic occultist with white dreadlocks and pink eyes who gives a prophetic tarot card reading to characters Raimi and Oran. Although Oran scorns her, she is not offended and claims that many people don't understand her condition. *The personification of [[Prussia]] in the anime/webcomic [[Hetalia: Axis Powers]] is commonly perceived by fans of the series to be an albino, because of his red eyes and silver-white hair. Whether or not he actually albinistic has not been discussed in the series canon, however. *Mr. Skimpole, a character in ''[[The Somnambulist]]'' at first seems evil, but is made more likable through his crippled son, whom he cares for (although the narrator insinuates that his son might be a fabrication, to make Skimpole seem more sympathetic). * Kevin Smith, the silent, knife-wielding British assassin in [[Goichi Suda]]'s ''[[Killer7]]'' video game, one of the seven Smith personalities the player may control. Although a protagonist, the character's occupation as a murderer is not particularly heroic. <small>''(See [[Killer7|main article]] for sources).''</small> * Theokoles, "the Shadow of Death", is an albinistic, pink-eyed [[gladiator]] in the fifth episode, "Shadow Games" (2010), of the [[Starz (TV network)|Starz]] TV series ''[[Spartacus: Blood and Sand]]''. He is depicted as a huge and greatly feared, savage warrior prone to blood-lust, "a beast that has never been tamed". Despite the fact that at least one review labels the character an "evil albino",<ref name="TVTropes Spartacus">{{cite web |url= http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ptitlelr67penz |author=<!--Staff writers; no by-line.--> |title=Spartacus: Blood and Sand |work=TVTropes.com |location=[[Rice Lake, Wisconsin]] |publisher=Gu Straley |year=2010 |access-date=3 March 2010 |dead-url=yes |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20100418213613/http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Ptitlelr67penz |archive-date=18 April 2010}}</ref> Theokoles is also said to have won many fortunes and his freedom via his long-undefeated string of victories in the arena, for which he is respected as well as feared by other gladiators. * The Underland humans from Suzanne Collins's "[[The Underland Chronicles]]" novel series are all albinistic, with violet eyes, since they live underground and are not exposed to the sun. They are portrayed as no different from any other race, with varying personalities. ''(See also The Banes, above.)'' * Hansberry in the film, [[A Guy Thing]] (2003). *The Anime/manga series "[[Deadman Wonderland]]" features an albino character named Shiro (Which is Japanese for "White"). She is introduced as an absurdly strong but ditzy and kind girl who knew the main character Ganta as a child and was in love with him. It is later revealed that Shiro is a split personality. Her secondary persona is called the Wretched Egg, a violent, psychopathic murderer. The Wretched Egg persona becomes one of the main antagonists while the Shiro persona struggles in vain to retake control. This puts her in the odd position of being both the villain and a victim. * Brynden Rivers, also known as Bloodraven for a birthmark on his neck, is an albino character in [[George R. R. Martin]]'s ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' who, while a bastard of the Targaryen bloodline, decided to not side with his rebelling siblings against the throne long before the series begins. He loses an eye during said rebellion, and serves the realm afterwards. Later he is revealed to still be living, although it us unclear if he is a villain or not thus far. * One of the ''sangomas'', or witchdoctors, in ''[[Shaka Zulu (TV series)|Shaka Zulu]]'' has albinism. *In [[Games Workshop]]'s [[tabletop game]] "[[Horus Heresy (2010 board game)|The Horus Heresy]]" the Emperor's Children Space Marine legion is described as having a gene-seed defect that results in an "occasional incidence of albinism, and a shift in iris colour to violet in some recruits." The Emperor's Children are initially depicted as being obsessed with achieving personal perfection in all ways, though they seemed not to care about this defect. They were the only legion allowed to bear the Emperor's name, and the only legion allowed to bear his personal standard, the "Palatine Aquila." However, they were also one of the legions which betrayed the Imperium during the Horus heresy event. Whether or not this makes them evil is entire subjective, as arguments can be made for both the Imperium and the Traitor Legions being good or evil. It is unknown whether this gene-seed defect still exists in [[Warhammer 40,000]] (of which the Horus Heresy is a spin-off game.) *In [[Kazuma Kamachi]]'s [[A Certain Magical Index]], Accelerator, is an esper with albinism due to his ability. At first he is portrayed as a villain in the story, but as the story progresses he is portrayed more of an anti-hero. <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** -->
;Animals and other non-humanoid characters * Moby Dick, an albino [[sperm whale]], in the book ''[[Moby-Dick]]''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Moby-Dick; or, the Whale|last=Melville|first=Herman|authorlink=Herman Melville|year=1851|publisher=Richard Bentley|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/2701/2701-h/2701-h.htm|chapter=The Whiteness of The Whale|quote=And of all these things the Albino whale was the symbol.|isbn=1-58729-906-2}}</ref> [[File:Alice par John Tenniel 02.png|thumb|upright|[[Lewis Carroll]]'s [[White Rabbit]] is arguably one of the most famous albino characters in literature.]] * The [[White Rabbit]] from [[Lewis Carroll]]'s ''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]]''. (Although Carroll did not specifically state that the character is albinistic, and not all white rabbits are albinos in real life, both the [[Alice in Wonderland (1951 film)|1951 adaptation]] and the [[Alice in Wonderland (2010 film)|2010 Tim Burton re-imagining]], among other more obscure versions, depict him as an albino, with pink eyes.) While the White Rabbit is timid and nervous, he is depicted as one of the saner and more intelligent denizens of Wonderland. * In [[C.S. Lewis]]'s novel ''[[Out of the Silent Planet]]'', the protagonist Ransom (an Englishman visiting [[Mars]]) encounters three species of intelligent [[Martians]]. One Martian individual is unpigmented.{{Clarify|date=September 2007}}<!--AND...? Tell us something about the character's portrayal.--> *El Blanco, in ''[[Tremors 3: Back to Perfection]]'', is an albino [[graboid]] that while inaccurately portrayed as being sterile as a result of albinism, otherwise behaves as any other predator of this sort in the film/TV series.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} *In the ''[[Perils of Penelope Pitstop]]'' episode "Arabian Desert Danger", Penelope tries to cross a desert to donate a young albino [[camel]] to a [[zoo]] without having to put the animal in danger. *Philip of Macedonia, Uncle Amos's pet crocodile from ''[[The Kane Chronicles]]''. *In ''[[Flushed Away]]'', an albino rat named Whitey is one of the villain's henchmen; although he works for the villain, he comes across as friendly and good-natured with no malicious intent (making him an ambiguous example rather than a clearly negative one). <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** -->
===Positively portrayed characters=== <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** --> {{Refimprove section|date=January 2007}} Persons with albinism are sometimes depicted heroically or otherwise positively, or at least accurately with regard to their condition and its medical and social results:
*Alexander Kramir, from the novel Lentara is a fairly accurately portrayed boy with Albinism who helps an alien race save the Earth and falls in love with an alien. He later fathers a child who will help save the universe.<ref>{{cite book|last=Campbell|first=Michelle|title=Lentara|year=2010|page=335}}</ref> * Bibwit Harte, Queen Alyss's albino tutor from [[Frank Beddor]]'s [[The Looking Glass Wars]]. A human version of the [[White Rabbit]] ''(see above)'' from [[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland]], he has large, unusually sensitive ears, and his name is an [[anagram]] of "white rabbit." * Dancy Flammarion, the monster-slaying heroine of [[Caitlín R. Kiernan]]'s ''Alabaster'' comics, as well as many prose stories by the author, including her novel ''Threshold'' and the short stories collected in [[Alabaster (short story collection)|''Alabaster.'']] *[[Beowulf Shaeffer|Beowulf "Bey" Shaeffer]], hero of several stories in [[Larry Niven]]'s [[Known Space]] series, from the planet We Made It, which is populated primarily by albinistic people due to a [[founder effect]] from the original colonists. <small>''(See [[Beowulf Shaeffer|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * Bran Davies, in "[[The Dark Is Rising]]" novel series, is a positive portrayal but somewhat inaccurate because the character lacks any vision problems. * [[Bjørn Beltø]], an archaeologist in [[Tom Egeland]]'s Norwegian novel ''Sirkelens Ende'' (''Circle's End''), {{ISBN|82-03-18974-1}}, which pre-dates but is very similar to ''[[The Da Vinci Code]]'', which incidentally features an albinistic person in a negative role while Egeland's novel does the opposite. * [[List of The Venture Bros. characters|Pete White]] in ''[[The Venture Bros.]]'' animated series on "[[Adult Swim]]". An albinistic computer scientist and friend of Dr. Venture from his college years, he runs "Conjectural Technologies" with Master Billy Quizboy, Boy Genius. The name is stereotypical (as per superhero convention), but his intelligence is accentuated, and the character is not otherwise mocked, although Dr. Venture makes a reference in the pilot to an experiment gone awry with a device called an "albino bomb." This line does not seem to be canon though. In an earlier career as a TV quiz host, he wore a black wig and used makeup in an attempt to appear "normal", although this fear came less from discrimination than from his own desire to be popular. * Misaki Saiki, an albinistic dominatrix, is the principle heroine in the ''[[Vulgar Ghost Daydream]]'' manga. She speaks to ghosts for a special government agency, but such fantasy is common in the genre. <small>''(See [[Vulgar Ghost Daydream|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * Billy Raven of the "[[Children of the Red King]]" novel series, an albinistic orphan initially manipulated into helping a villain, is overall a sympathetic character. Realistically, he needs eyeglasses; unrealistically, he has the magic ability to talk to animals, although his supernatural abilities are said to not be related to his albinism (cf. "Snow" and "Powder", etc., above). * [[Geralt of Rivia]] from Andrzej Sapowski's 'The Witcher' series. * Whylas (played by Dennis Hurley who has albinism), in ''[[The Albino Code]]'', a 2007 short film parodying ''The Da Vinci Code''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s Silas (as well as the ''Matrix Reloaded'' twins). In the parody, Whylas has realistic vision problems that make him hilariously incompetent as an assassin, a job he doesn't want anyway, being just a regular guy. * Setsuna Sakurazaki of the manga ''[[Negima!]]'' is stated to be an albino who regularly dyes her hair and wears contact lenses to hide her albinism. <small>''(See [[Setsuna Sakurazaki|main article]] for sources.)''</small> * Peter Smart in Adam Salter's 2007 novel ''The Platinum Prison'' ({{ISBN|978-1847534415}}) is an albinistic man, tortured by the label "albino", who "tries...to find his place in life and search[es] for acceptance and love" in the late 1960s and early 1970s.<ref name="Salter 2007">{{cite book |title=The Platinum Prison |isbn=978-1-84753-441-5 |last=Salter |first=Adam |location=[[Raleigh, North Carolina]] |publisher=[[Lulu (company)|Lulu Ent]] |year=2007 |at=back cover blurb}}</ref> * Persephone "Percy" Parker, "an albino orphan with a talent for languages",<ref name="PubWeek2009">{{cite web |title=Review: ''The Strangely Beautiful Tale of Miss Percy Parker'' |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |url= https://www.amazon.com/dp/0843962968 |work=[[Publishers Weekly]] |issn=0000-0019 |location=[[New York City|New York]] |publisher=[[Reed Business Information]] |accessdate=21 September 2009}}</ref> in [[Leanna Renee Hieber]]'s Gothic occult novels set in Victorian London, is a sympathetic character described as a beautiful and intelligent young woman, with a normal love life and the respect of colleagues. * The Albino Pirate from [[Gideon Defoe]]'s ''[[The Pirates!]]'' series is a fan favorite character, noted for his kindness, youthful inexperience, and naivete. While his condition is occasionally exploited or misunderstood, he is always portrayed fairly, and his albinism is not the central focus of his character. (While his name, or lack thereof, seems to indicate otherwise, all the pirates are named for one noticeable feature, e.g. The Pirate With Gout or The Pirate With A Scarf.) * [[List of Metal Gear characters|Strangelove]], an albino bisexual artificial intelligence developer from [[Metal Gear (series)|Metal Gear]] series. * The playable avatar from ''[[Fire Emblem Fates]]'' (named Corrin by default) has traits of [[albinism]], though this is only by default since this character can be customized. * Sunny, the heroine of fantasy novel [[Akata Witch]] by [[Nnedi Okorafor]], is an American-born Nigerian girl with albinism who discovers her magical abilities and enters the world of the Leopard People. <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** -->
;Animals and other non-humanoid characters * Dangerous Beans, an [[Anthropomorphism|anthropomorphic]] albino rat in [[Terry Pratchett]]'s children's novel, ''[[The Amazing Maurice and His Educated Rodents]]'', is the most intelligent and peaceful of the group,{{Clarify|date=December 2009|reason=Group of what?}} and a kind of spiritual leader. He is almost totally blind. *Urthwyte the Mighty, an [[anthropomorphic]] albino badger in the "[[Redwall]]"-series fantasy novel ''[[Salamandastron]]'' by [[Brian Jacques]]. He is portrayed as a kind, gentle and talented leader. * Chobbal, an albino [[camel]], is the hero of ''Sophie and the Albino Camel'' and other books by British children's author [[Stephen Mark Davies|Stephen Davies]]. He experiences rejection by his own mother, and is fed and nurtured by a young African boy. He has a cheerful and generous disposition.<ref name="Chobbal">[http://www.tes.co.uk/search/story/?story_id=2261975 "Times Educational Supplement: An Awkward Age"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224172049/http://www.tes.co.uk/search/story/?story_id=2261975 |date=24 December 2007 }}.</ref> *Ghost, in [[George R. R. Martin]]'s ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'', is an albino [[dire wolf]] trained to aid his companion [[Jon Snow (character)|Jon Snow]], and does so many times, as the second most frequently referred to companion animal of this sort in the story. * The ''[[Magic: The Gathering]]'' character Ajani Goldmane is an albino leonid (a race of fictional [[anthropomorphic]] [[lion]]s). Once saw as a bad omen from his own tribe for his condition, after the brother's death he became a "Planeswalker", a powerful being capable to travel to the other planes of the game's multiverse (a trait secluded to most of the other living beings). <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** -->
===Other references to albinism=== <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** --> {{Unreferenced section|date=December 2009}}
====Comics==== * [[Albino (comics)|Albino]] is the alias of two Marvel Comics supervillains, Augusta Seger and Ulysses Counts. In Augusta Seger's backstory, he acquired the nickname "Albino" in school because of his pale skin, he grew up to become a criminal, and was recruited into the Power Men supervillain team and given a serum which allowed him to mimic others' superpowers. After Augusta was arrested, he accidentally transferred his powers to Ulysses Counts, his friend and old partner in crime, who gained the ability to phase through solid objects, used that power to escape from jail, and assumed the alias of Albino.
====Film==== * James, a character in ''[[Shortbus]]'', had a catchphrase, "I'm an albino!" that he used as a child star in a fictitious sitcom about a [[White people|white]] child growing up in a [[Black people|black]] family. In the film, he has grown up, and people use "I'm an albino!" as a greeting to him at parties. He and his partner also gleefully shout the phrase while having sex. At one party, a man with albinism comes up to James and talks to him, saying "I really am an albino" (although played by [[Reg Vermue]], who has normal pigment in real life).
====Music==== * "An albino" (along with "a [[mulatto]]") features prominently in the [[refrain|chorus]] of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana's]] hit song about teenage angst and high school factionalism, "[[Smells Like Teen Spirit]]".
====Television==== *''[[Sons of Anarchy]]'' season 2, episode 1, titled "[[Albification]]", concerns "whitewashing" various unpleasant truths, and introduces L.O.A.N., a new (fictional) [[white supremacist]] organization, which strives to prevent the titular motorcycle club of the show from doing business with [[people of color]]. <!-- *** READ THE HTML COMMENT NEAR THE TOP OF THE "Fiction" SECTION BEFORE ADDING TO THIS LIST! *** --> <!-- Please do not uncomment this commented-out section; it is still in progress. ===Unknown; research pending=== * ?, in [[John Carpenter]]'s "[[Children of the Damned]]''<ref name="skinema5" /> * "The Hippie Albino"{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}} (played possibly by a real person with albinism), in ''[[Not Another Teen Movie]]'' (2001).<ref name="skinema5" /> * ''[[Treehouse of Horror VIII]]'' (''[[The Simpsons]]'' Halloween Special) (1997) * ?, in ''[[Albino (film)|Albino]]'' (1976). (He is a violent cult leader)<ref name="skinema2" /> * ?, in ''[[The Life and Time of Judge Roy Bean]]'' (1972) * ? (played by [[Bernie Casey]]), in ''[[Dr. Black, Mr. Hyde]]'' (1976) (a pimp).<ref name="skinema2" /> * ? (played by Victor Varnado), in ''[[The Adventures of Pluto Nash]]''<ref name="skinema2" /> * ? [is it the banjo kid?], in ''[[Deliverance]]''. (Allegedly a positive portrayal.)<ref name="skinema2" /> * Rizpah, a character in the historic Roman Mysteries, is described as having pale skin, white hair and pink eyes. She helps Jonathan escape the Golden Palace and kill an assassin. -->
==Myths, folklore, and urban legends== {{anchor|Folklore, urban legends and myths|reason=Old section name, may be linked to.}}
===Africa=== In [[Zimbabwe]], modern [[folklore]] posits that sexual intercourse with an albinistic person will cure one of [[HIV]], leading to the [[rape]] (and subsequent HIV infection) of women with albinism in that region.<ref>{{cite news|last=Machipisa |first=Lewis |url=http://ipsnews.net/interna.asp?idnews=14122 |title=RIGHTS-ZIMBABWE: The Last Minority Group to Find a Voice |publisher=Inter Press Service |date=25 November 2002 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090121145742/http://ipsnews.net/interna.asp?idnews=14122 |archivedate=21 January 2009 }}</ref>
In [[Tanzania]] in 2008, President [[Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete|Kikwete]] publicly condemned [[African witchcraft|witch doctor]]s for opportunistic [[persecution of albinism]], including a spate of murders of albinistic people (over 50 since March 2007, as of October 2008,<ref name="kii">{{cite web |url= http://allafrica.com/stories/200810200901.html |first=Orton |last=Kiishweko |title=Tanzania: JK Orders Crackdown to Stem Murder of Albinos |date=20 October 2008 |publisher=The Citizen |location=Dar es Salaam}}</ref> and initially limited to Tanzania) for their body parts which are thought to bring good luck – hair, arms, legs and blood are used to make potions which the witchdoctors claim will bring prosperity. Consequently, graves of the albinistic have to be sealed with cement to discourage grave robbers.<ref name="bbc727">{{Cite news |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7527729.stm |title=Tanzania Albinos Targeted Again |work=BBC News |date=27 July 2008 |access-date=27 July 2008 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080728005602/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7527729.stm |archive-date=28 July 2008 |dead-url=no}}</ref><ref name="nyt">{{Cite news |title=Albinos, Long Shunned, Face Threat in Tanzania |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=8 June 2008 |last=Gettleman |first=Jeffrey |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/08/world/africa/08albino.html}}</ref><ref name="BBC-049">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/7518049.stm |title=Living in fear: Tanzania's albinos |work=BBC News |date=21 July 2008 |access-date=17 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="Independent">{{Cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/crackdown-on-witchdoctors-after-albinos-killed-to-harvest-body-parts-804545.html |title=Crackdown on Witchdoctors After Albinos Killed to Harvest Body Parts |first=Claire |last=Soares |date=4 April 2008 |work=[[The Independent]] |department="World: Africa" section |location=London |accessdate=16 December 2009}}</ref> By June 2008 killings had been reported in neighboring [[Kenya]] and possibly also the [[Democratic Republic of Congo]],<ref name="nyt" /><ref name="kul">{{cite web |url=http://www.canada.com/topics/news/world/story.html?id=d9487de6-5eeb-4b6e-b21f-4863db51113c |title=Crackdown Vowed After Tanzania Albino Girl Killed, Mutilated |first=John |last=Kulekana |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=21 October 2008 |access-date=22 April 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105100148/http://www.canada.com/topics/news/world/story.html?id=d9487de6-5eeb-4b6e-b21f-4863db51113c |archive-date=5 November 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> spreading to [[Burundi]] by October 2008.<ref name="afp">{{cite web |url= http://www.france24.com/20081014-burundis-albinos-flee-sorcerers-organ-traders |first=Esdras |last=Ndikumanna |title=Burundi's albinos flee sorcerers and organ traders |publisher=Agence France-Presse |date=14 October 2008 |dead-url=yes |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090929003917/http://www.france24.com/20081014-burundis-albinos-flee-sorcerers-organ-traders |archive-date=29 September 2009}}</ref> ''(See [[Persecution of people with albinism]] for more information.)''
===Caribbean=== In [[Jamaica]], people with albinism were historically degraded, and regarded as "[[curse]]d".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://abcnews.go.com/Health/story?id=5323052&page=1|title=Being Albino: Fighting the Stigma|last=News|first=A. B. C.|date=2008-09-30|website=ABC News|language=en|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Carnegie|first=Charles V.|date=1996|title=The Dundus and the Nation|url=https://anthrosource.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1525/can.1996.11.4.02a00030|journal=Cultural Anthropology|language=en|volume=11|issue=4|pages=470–509|doi=10.1525/can.1996.11.4.02a00030|issn=0886-7356|via=}}</ref> In recent times, the albinistic musicians King [[Yellowman]] and [[Al Beeno]] have helped to curb this stereotype.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hagerman|first=Brent|date=2015|title=Thank you Jah Jah fe give me this a colour: Yellowman's revalorization of thedundus|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Ffull%2F10.1080%2F13504630.2015.1106311|journal=Social Identities|language=en|volume=21|issue=6|pages=529–544|doi=10.1080/13504630.2015.1106311|issn=1350-4630|via=}}</ref>
===North America=== The 2004 book ''Weird N.J.''<ref name="WeirdNJ1">{{Cite book |last1=Moran |first1=Mark |last2=Sceurman |first2=Mark |title=Weird N.J.: Your Travel Guide to New Jersey's Local Legends and Best Kept Secrets |date=2003 |publisher=Sterling Publications |isbn=0-7607-3979-X}}</ref> (a tie-in to the [[History (U.S. TV channel)|History Channel]] TV series ''[[Weird U.S.]]'') chronicled, failed to prove, yet further popularized one of the lesser-known local [[urban legend]]s of the US, "albino colonies". The book uses alleged firsthand accounts mailed to the authors to paint a picture of various locations in the U.S. (most notably [[Clifton, New Jersey]]) where aggregations of albinistic families were said to live in seclusion. The accounts tell tales of honking horns to try to bring the residents out of their houses, of gawkers being shot at by residents, and even of gangs of local albinistic [[vigilante]]s.
In some versions of the [[sewer alligator]] urban legends, the alligators supposedly became albinistic due to mutation (which is implausible due to the short time scale) and/or lack of exposure to sunlight (which erroneously conflates pallor due to lack of exposure to sunlight with albinism).<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.delorenzosdugout.com/urbanlegends.htm |work=New York Daily News Online |title=Tales From the Urban Crypt |access-date=8 January 2010 |dead-url=yes |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20080515224141/http://www.delorenzosdugout.com/urbanlegends.htm |archive-date=15 May 2008}}<!--See if snopes.com has something on this; it would be a more reliable source, anyway.--></ref>
===South America=== Among the [[Kuna (people)|Kuna]] of [[Panama]] and [[Colombia]], members with albinism have a special place in the [[Indigenous peoples|indigenous]] [[mythology]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Jeambrun|first=Pascale|date=1998|title=Oculocutaneous albinism: Clinical, historical and anthropological aspects|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0929693X9880136X|journal=Archives de Pédiatrie|volume=5|issue=8|pages=896–907|pmid=9759297|via=}}</ref> While they are regarded as physically inferior, they are, at the same time, regarded as 'closer to God' and in possession of special powers.<ref name="Stout">{{Cite journal|last=Stout|first=D. B.|date=1946|title=Further notes on albinism among the san blas Cuna, Panama|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/ajpa.1330040408|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|volume=4|issue=4|pages=483-490, here p. 489|doi=10.1002/ajpa.1330040408|via=}}</ref> At times of eclipses, the Kunas believe their members with albinism are able to scare away with bow and arrow the demon who devours the sun or moon.<ref name="Stout" />
==Film and television coverage of discrimination against albinism== Due to a wave of [[persecution of people with albinism]] in some parts of [[Africa]] (especially [[Tanzania]] and neighboring countries) – including ritual murder and dismemberment for potions and good-luck charms – a number of [[documentary film]]s have been made about the problem. These include ''[[In My Genes]]'' ([[Kenya]], 2009), ''[[White and Black: Crimes of Color]]'' ([[Canada]]/Tanzania, 2010), and ''[[In the Shadow of the Sun (documentary)|In the Shadow of the Sun]]'' (Tanzania, 2013). {{Crossref|(For more information, see {{section link|Persecution of people with albinism|Films highlighting persecution of albinism}}.)}}
Also released in 2013, [[White Shadow (film)|''White Shadow'']], an award-winning [[Germany|German]]–[[Italy|Italian]]–Tanzanian [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]], portrays the plight of albinistic Tanzanians and their efforts to avoid falling victim to witchdoctors' bounty hunters.
Outside the African context, the 2007 short film "Perception Is Not Reality: Portraying the REAL Truths About Albinism", dispelling Hollywood and urban-legend nonsense about the condition, was produced by Mashawna Thompson, editor of the ''Parent of a Child with Albinism'' blog.<ref>{{cite web |title=Perception Is Not Reality: Portraying the REAL Truths About Albinism |first=Mashawna |last=Thompson |date=1 August 2011 |orig-year=2007 |work=PerceptionIsNotReality.com |url=http://PerceptionIsNotReality.com |access-date=14 October 2015}} Originally released on the now-defunct OneTrueMedia.com platform.</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Welcome |work=Parent of a Child with Albinism |url= http://www.parentofachildwithalbinism.com/ |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150308090944/http://www.parentofachildwithalbinism.com/ |archive-date=8 March 2015 |access-date=14 October 2015}}</ref> A new version, featuring over 40 different children with albinism, was released in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |title=Perception is Not Reality |first=Mashawna |last=Thompson |date=31 May 2014 |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sHHz8IBAoW4 |website=YouTube |access-date=14 October 2015}}</ref> The theme of the aforementioned ''[[The Albino Code]]'' (2007) is to point out the absurdity of typical depictions of albinistic people in Western media. In 2009, two [[African American]] albinistic [[fashion model]]s, [[Shaun Ross (model)|Shaun Ross]] and [[Diandra Forrest]], were the focus of an episode of the ''[[Tyra Banks Show]]'', and revealed the traumas they experienced growing up albinistic, before finding unexpected success in front of the camera.<ref name="Tyra.com">{{cite web |date=2009 |title=Redefining Beauty: Shaun Ross |work=Tyra.com |url=http://www.tyra.com/view/story_06ABOUT_FACE |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20091102091805/http://www.tyra.com/view/story_06ABOUT_FACE |archive-date=2 November 2009 |accessdate=14 October 2015}} This short piece covers Banks's meeting Ross which led up to the episode. The site is now defunct, and no video is available from it (or even images), though the episode can be found on YouTube and similar sites. Exact airdate uncertain.</ref> <!--Add some more documentaries here. Most of them are short films, and usually about modeling and portrait photography being used to break through stereotype barriers. There should be one findable somewhere on Guidotti's work in this vein. -->

Harishankar]], a [[Carnatic music|Carnatic]] ''khanjira'' drummer<ref name="seemain" /> *[[Krondon|Marvin "Krondon" Jones III]], an American [[Rapping|rapper]] and actor<ref name="seemain" /> *[[Zephania Kameeta]], a Namibian religious and political leader<ref name="seemain" /> *[[File:Stanley Sataan Kaoni.jpg|thumb|right|155px|Stanley "Sataan" Kaoni, 2002]] [[Stanley Kaoni]] (also known as "Sataan"), a former [[Solomon Islands]] militant leader (Kaoni has light blonde hair and pale facial skin with some evidence of [[vitiligo]], and appears to have developed some pigmentation especially on the arms; his particular type of albinism is likely to be OCA1b.)<ref name="SARA-FP">{{cite web|url=http://www.sara-foundation.com/famous_people.htm |title=Famous People with Albinism |work=SARA-Foundation.com |publisher=Supporting Albinism Research and Awareness |year=2005 |location=Campbell, California |accessdate=26 April 2008 |last=Centers |first=S. |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080423145250/http://www.sara-foundation.com/famous_people.htm |archive-date=23 April 2008 |dead-url=yes}}</ref><ref>[http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/WO0206/S00093.htm "Images: NZ Leaves Solomon Islands", from New Zealand Defence Force press release, published in ''Scoop Independent News''] (online edition); 26 June 2002; Wellington, New Zealand; accessed 8 January 2007. Today, in [[Persian language|Persian]] ''zaal'' is a term for albinistic people.<ref name="seemain" /> <!-- Please keep this list alphabetized by family name, or first nicknames if no family name given. --> <!-- DO NOT PUT FICTIONAL CHARACTERS HERE PLEASE; that is what the "Fiction" section above is for. -->
===People commonly mistaken to have albinism=== [[Roy Orbison]] was falsely said to be albinistic, by his widow, for unknown reasons.<ref name="Orbison">[http://oldies.about.com/od/60srockers/p/royorbison.htm Oldies Music Guide Profile: Roy Orbison], by Robert Fontenot, [[About.com]]; accessed 27 January 2007.</ref> German singer [[Heino]] has [[Graves disease]], which can be mistaken for albinism. Actor [[Anthony Rapp]] (of ''[[Star Trek: Discovery]]'') fronts a rock band called Albinokid, but is not albinistic, being a normally pigmented, blonde [[White people|Caucasian]]. Former Mayor of London [[Boris Johnson]], known for his pale hair, has also been mistakenly called albino.{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} In general, platinum blonde ("towheaded") people with very pale skin can be mistaken for albinistic (and conversely, some forms of albinism can result in [[phenotypes]] so normal-looking that only genetic testing can reveal the albinistic genes).
==Notable albino animals== [[File:snowdrop.penguin.600pix.jpg|thumb|left|180px|Snowdrop, an albino African Penguin, born at Bristol Zoo (England). Snowdrop would otherwise have looked like the background penguins]] An albino [[humpback whale]] called [[Migaloo]] ([[Indigenous Australian languages|Australian Aboriginal]] for "White Lad") travels the east coast of Australia, and has become famous in the local media.<ref name="MigalooSite">[http://www.migaloowhale.org/ ''MigalooWhale.org''], [[Pacific Whale Foundation]]; [[Maui, Hawaii]], USA, 2007; accessed 11 April 2007.</ref><ref name="SMH1">[http://www.smh.com.au/news/Environment/Stormy-seas-for-Migaloo-and-friends/2005/04/19/1113854200051.html "Stormy seas for Migaloo and friends"]; Darby, Andrew; ''Sydney Morning Herald'', [[Sydney, Australia|Sydney]], Australia, 20 April 2005; accessed 11 April 2007</ref> [[Bristol Zoo]] was the home to a very rare albino [[African penguin]] named Snowdrop, who was hatched at the zoo in October 2002 and died in August 2004.<ref name="BBCNews1">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/2572205.stm "Albino Penguin 'One-in-a-million'"], no by-line, ''BBC News'' (online edition), 13 December 2002. Retrieved 11 April 2007.</ref><ref name="BBCNews2">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/england/bristol/somerset/3579986.stm "Zoo's Rare Albino Penguin Is Dead"], no by-line, ''BBC News'' (online edition), 19 August 2004. Retrieved 11 April 2007.</ref> For many years, a unique albino [[gorilla]] named [[Floquet de Neu]] in [[Catalan language|Catalan]] and Copito de Nieve in Spanish (both meaning "Snowflake"), was the most famous resident of the Parc Zoològic de [[Barcelona]].<ref name="FloquetDeNeu.es">[http://www.floquetdeneu.es/Eng/Homeeng.html ''FloquetDeNeu.es''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615085639/http://www.floquetdeneu.es/Eng/Homeeng.html |date=15 June 2007 }}, Parc Zoològic de [[Barcelona]], date of publication unknown (no earlier than 24 November 2003); accessed 11 April 2007.</ref> In 2009 a pink albino [[bottlenose dolphin]], nicknamed [[Pinky (dolphin)|Pinky]], was sighted several times in an inland lake in the United States,<ref name="Telegraph">[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/howaboutthat/4927224/Pink-dolphin-appears-in-US-lake.html "Pink dolphin appears in US lake"]; ''Telegraph'', United Kingdom, 5 March 2009; accessed 7 March 2009</ref> and footage of it has become popular on Internet video sites. There is also an albino crocodile in Jungle Island theme park in Miami, Fl.
Perhaps the most significant albino animal in history was [[Mocha Dick]], a [[sperm whale]] of the early 19th century that lived mostly near the island of [[Mocha (island)|Mocha]], off [[Chile]]'s southern Pacific coast, several decades before [[Herman Melville]] fictionalized him in the 1851 novel ''[[Moby-Dick]]''. The real whale was renowned for being docile until attacked whereupon he became ferocious and capable of disabling smaller vessels. This made him widely feared among [[whaler]] crews, though also a target for adventurous captains, who engaged him in possibly as many as hundred or more sea battles before he was eventually killed.{{clear}}
